title: Does quantum entanglement occur in the brain? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Does quantum entanglement occur in the brain?” While quantum entanglement is an aspect of most low-level physical phenomenon, it is very short range among atoms. BTW, what I’m going to say is about the same thing Ojvind Bernander wrote succinctly in his collapsed answer. The problem with a question like this is that we don’t fully understand entanglement and there is much we don’t understand about how the brain works. So let me walk you through how a scientist might approach a question like this. A scientist balances evidence for and against the idea that quantum entanglement contributes substantially to brain function. For: We know that neurons in the brain are tiny, and we know they have internal structures that are even tinier. One theory of quantum mechanical effects in the brain suggest that microtubules, which are a fundamental component for every cell, might have internal structures small enough to participate in entanglement.That’s it.Against: We have seen no evidence of quantum entanglement occurring in the brain.While a tubule is small enough to hold a quantum state, the distance between neurons is larger than we have seen sustained entanglement at body temperature.We have no theory about how entanglement would contribute to brain function.We don’t have a central mystery that quantum entanglement is necessary to solve.The mysteries we have (memory, cognition, etc.) seem to be adequately explainable with neural networks, even if we don’t yet have those explanations at hand.So we don’t reject the possibility that quantum entanglement contributes to brain function. It’s a possibility that is left in the background as we pursue more likely answers.

Here’s how that entanglement misnomer got started: By 1930 Einstein had noticed information could be found in quantum mechanical systems that could not have been communicated at speeds less than c. Of course communication is not meaningful in solutions in deterministic systems: the entire timespan of the solution is present in the state at any moment.[1] Einstein had discovered that Q.M. was deterministic just like all the rest of physics, but in that unfamiliar context he found it spooky and he said so in 1935. Schrodinger immediately coined ”quantum entanglement” in agreement. The idea that Q.M. is not deterministic stems from a misinterpretation of Max Born’s 1926 method for saying at least something about the effects of electrodynamic interactions not representable in any of the 1910–1928 Q.M. models. Lacking electrodynamics, the 1910–1928 Q.M. models have only stationary fundamental solutions. Substantial agreement with spectrographic data from real atoms shows that real atoms spend a lot of time in quasistationary states that are spectrally well approximated by the stationary states of the models. Born estimated the quasistationary state of a real atom just after an unmodelable electrodynamic interaction in terms of a stationary state modeling the real atom’s quasistationary state just before the interaction, as a linear combination of the stationary states of the models. Of course the stationary states of the models do not jump into linear superpositions of themselves: they are entirely stationary. Born’s estimate doesn’t change that. Q.M. and its solutions are entirely deterministic, just like all the rest of physics. The probabilistic interpretation has been applied to every result in Q.M. since 1926, and even to the evolution of our universe! Nope, the universe itself and all of physics are entirely deterministic: Q.M. is simply incomplete. “Spooky action at a distance” and “quantum entanglement” both describe nothing more than the determinism common to all of physics! [1] A system is called deterministic if the states of its time-dependent solutions at any moment determine the entire timespans of the solutions. Boscovich formulated the physical principle of determinism in his 1758 Theoria philosophiae naturalis, 50 years before Laplace’s brief and more metaphysical statement.

It probably does occasionally – your brain is made out of quarks and electrons after all – but it has no relevance whatsoever to the functioning of the brain. Consciousness has nothing whatsoever to do with quantum mechanics. At least not in any important or meaningful way. The processes that lead to consciousness are many levels removed from the quantum level. Trying to understand how the brain works by studying QM would be like trying to figure out why traffic jams happen by looking at brake fluid under a microscope. Yes, at some very deep level, a traffic jam is ultimately “caused by” brake fluid, but that’s not an appropriate or interesting level of description to look at. If we are say, a city planner trying to redesign an on-ramp, we need to investigate the emergent phenomenon of a traffic jam many layers of structure higher than brake fluid. Same goes for the brain. If we are interested in how the brain works, we will almost certainly never learn anything interesting or important by applying quantum mechanics.

Yes, entanglement occurs whenever two particles interact. Also, entanglement is “contagious”: when A is entangled with B, and B later interacts with C, A and C are now entangled. So you can be that all the atoms in the brain are entangled. Furthermore, the atoms in your brain are, by contagion, entangled with zillions of particles outside the visible universe. As Schollhauer says in his Decoherence book: entanglement is everywhere. Warning: New Age spiritualists will take this to mean all sorts of stuff that it doesn’t. Telepathy. Vibrations. Wishful thinking. We’re all connected… Entanglement is only useful when it can be very, very carefully controlled. As light and air molecules bounce off objects, skulls, brains, neurons… entanglement is not controlled.

The brain is a mass of molecules that interact with no pause, and they exchange energy and information so yes, a complicated form of quantum entanglement called decoherence (information exchange by measurement) accompanied by quantum dissipation (relaxation to the ground state by loss of energy to a heat bath with many degrees of freedom) occurs between brain molecules as well as with the environment because the brain is a measurement device for the environment. Measurement devices are always entangled with the particles they measure.
